#Repost @humansofny ・・・ “When is the time you felt most broken?”
“I first ran for Congress in 1999, and I got beat. I just got whooped. I had been in the state legislature for a long time, I was in the minority party, I wasn’t getting a lot done, and I was away from my family and putting a lot of strain on Michelle. Then for me to run and lose that bad, I was thinking maybe this isn’t what I was cut out to do. I was forty years old, and I’d invested a lot of time and effort into something that didn’t seem to be working. But the thing that got me through that moment, and any other time that I’ve felt stuck, is to remind myself that it’s about the work. Because if you’re worrying about yourself—if you’re thinking: ‘Am I succeeding? Am I in the right position? Am I being appreciated?’ --- then you’re going to end up feeling frustrated and stuck. But if you can keep it about the work, you’ll always have a path. There’s always something to be done.”

“During my campaign, I spent a lot of time in 1999 and 2000 here in Buffalo. I stayed at one of the hotels, and I got to know the people who worked at the hotel. I would talk with them and greet them and thank them. And the very last time I was here, right before the election of 2000—so it probably would have been the weekend before the election—as I was getting ready to leave, one of the maids came up to me… she said, 'I want to ask you something.' I said, 'What is it?' She said, 'Please don’t forget Buffalo.' And she handed me a little snow globe with a little Buffalo inside. I put that on my dresser. When you have a sick spouse and you can’t get time off to care for your husband or your wife, or you have an ailing older relative and you can’t get time off to care for that mother, that father, that grandparent, what kind of society are we that we don’t let people do the most important work there is, caring for each other, supporting each other? Today on César Chávez Day, we honor his commitment to service, education, and equal opportunity for all. Born on this day in 1927, he championed the labor movement and empowered working communities. As co-founders of the United Farm Workers, he and Dolores Huerta fought for and won higher wages, better working conditions, and the right to unionize—giving more workers the opportunity to build a better future. | Hoy honramos a César Chávez y celebramos su dedicación al servicio, la educación y la igualdad de oportunidades para todos. César Chávez nació un día como hoy en 1927 y dedicó su vida al movimiento laboral y empoderar a las comunidades trabajadoras. Como co-fundador de la Unión de Campesinos, Chávez junto a Dolores Huertas luchó y consiguió mejores salarios, mejores condiciones de trabajo y el derecho a organizarse en sindicatos. Su esfuerzo resultó en mejores oportunidades y un mejor futuro para los trabajadores.

Happy birthday to Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the second female justice and a lifelong fighter for equal rights. Having paved the way for women and experienced sex discrimination herself at various points of her life—the first tenured woman at Columbia Law School and co-founder of the women’s rights project at the ACLU, who had once been rejected for a clerkship because of her gender—she dedicated her career to protecting women’s rights under the Constitution. As a litigator in the 1970s, she argued some of the most important cases against sex discrimination before the Supreme Court; as a Justice, she’s fought to protect the rights of women and all Americans.

Sisters and Brothers - We are on a path towards victory, and we took three more steps down that path last night with three YUGE wins in Alaska, Hawaii and Washington. We won each of those states with more than 68 percent of the vote, same as we did last week in Idaho, Utah, and Democrats Abroad. We are significantly shrinking Hillary Clinton's lead, and we're going to keep it up.

YOU are the momentum for our campaign. When you vote, caucus, volunteer, or make a contribution, you are building our momentum. Every ballot, every phone call or door knocked, and every dollar moves us forward. We are only doing so well because millions of people want us to do well. No billionaires, no super PACs. Just you, and the rest of our political revolution.

When working people and young people, when people who have given up on the political process get involved, that's how we win. They demand a government that represents them and not the 1 percent of our country. And if enough of us come together, they'll get it.

Right now we have the momentum. Momentum is having 14,000 people out in a rally in #SaltLakeCity about a week ago and 15,000 in #Seattle on Monday night. Momentum is in election after election, winning an overwhelming percentage of young people who are participating in the democratic process. Momentum is having rallies and town meetings that have brought out more than one million people over the course of this campaign.

What we are seeing is that the people of this country want to make it a better country. They are prepared to stand up and fight and take on the major crises that we face. They want an economy that works for all of us, not just wealthy campaign contributors. They want the United States of America to join every other major country and guarantee health care to all people as a right.

Conservative, progressive, Republican, or Democrat — they are all embarrassed by a corrupt campaign finance system that allows billionaires to buy elections.

And so they are fighting back, with almost 6 million contributions from nearly 2 million people, at an average of about $27 apiece

The Obama Administration exempts thousands of businesses from the HHS abortion-pill mandate. But when it comes to applying the same exemptions to nuns, priests, and religious schools, the federal government refuses to do so. Instead, it threatens to fine organizations, like Little Sisters of the Poor, up to $70 million for not funding services they find morally objectionable.
I hope the Supreme Court will decide to #letthemserve, and not force religious institutions to choose between their conscience and an unjust mandate. These are people of faith seeking to serve the most vulnerable communities, and rather than assisting their efforts, this administration is crippling their ability to do so. Faith fines have no place in our democracy.

Today the world remembers the greatest atrocity in human history. The utter horror of the #Holocaust must never be forgotten.
We mourn for the millions of people who lost their lives and the families who lost their loved ones. And we honor the heroism of the Jewish people — and all those who were persecuted — their courage will always reverberate throughout the world.
As we honor the memory of the six million, we must rededicate our efforts to fighting tyranny and jihad around the world, to combatting anti-Semitism — whether in Europe or on our own college campuses, and to preventing Iran’s Ayatollah Khamenei, or any other dictator, from acquiring weapons of mass destruction.
We must defeat evil with truth and resolve — and that begins with honoring the brave survivors and victims so that together we ensure that never again does such an atrocity occur. #NeverForget #NeverAgain

National #SchoolChoice Week reaffirms our shared commitment to giving all children, regardless of zip code, the opportunity to pursue the best education possible.

Parents should be able to choose the schools that best meet the educational needs of their children – whether public, charter, private, faith-based, or home school. 
Every child in #America deserves the chance to get a quality education and work to achieve the American Dream.

Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. understood the American potential more fully than it was actualized at the time. He challenged the distorted conventional acceptance of a “separate but equal” citizenry.

Today, we celebrate this sojourner of justice, and we remember his sacrifice. Because of his persistent struggle on the road towards freedom; because of his vision for an America in which men and women, boys and girls, of every race would learn, work, and pray side-by-side, we now have made great national strides to embrace the inherent dignity of humanity.

#Christmas is upon us again, a time not only to cherish the company of loved ones, but also to celebrate and heed the Lord – to remember that Holy Night in Bethlehem when Christ was born.

I pray your Christmas season is filled with joy and peace. May God bless you, and may He continue to bless the great state of Texas and the United States of America.

Heidi and I wish the Jewish Community a very #HappyChanukah.

On this holiday, we remember the miracle that enabled a freedom-loving people – led by the heroic Maccabees – to defeat the oppressive dictator Antiochus so that they could once again freely worship the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

America stands with the Jewish people both at home and abroad in protecting the light of faith and liberty.

On Dec. 7, 1941, a quiet Sunday morning, an ordinary day of rest became a “Day of Infamy.” A day that took more than 2,000 of our service members and citizens. A day that set aflame #PearlHarbor. 
Americans rose courageously against the threat to our freedom. Congress declared war on Japan the very next day – before Congress, President Franklin D. My Government will abolish the Tribunal that #BillShorten set up that will force tens of thousands of owner truck drivers out of business.

We will use the $4 million a year saved to fund #road-safety initiatives that will make a real contribution to reducing road accidents.

We believe owner drivers should  be able to set their own rates.  We reject #Labor's way that a #Government tribunal dictates the rates of small family businesses  while big trucking companies can charge whatever they like.

Pauline and Glen Kearney started a trucking business 20 years ago.  They own two trucks which they drive with their son Matt (their other son Jack hopes to join the business when he's old enough). Australia thrives when people like Pauline and Glen have a go - when they raise money, when they invest and work hard to build up their business.

Because of a deal Bill Shorten made with the Transport Workers Union they are being forced out of business, along with tens of thousands of other truck owner drivers.

We back Pauline and Glen and the thousands of other owner drivers - small businessmen and women, family businesses. We will always back those Australians who have backed themselves and whose enterprise is securing our prosperity and the economic growth on which our future depends.

The Kenbi claim made by the Larrakia people of the Cox Peninsula near Darwin have one of the oldest running native title claims in Australia’s history. 
It was lodged in 1979 and has not been settled in almost 40 years. 
Despite the injustices and the trauma, aboriginal communities like the Larrakia people have shown the greatest tenacity and resilience. 
Today Minister Nigel Scullion and NT Chief Minister Adam Giles met with Raylene Singh and traditional owners who have led the Kenbi claim, and they have given their consent to a proposal made by the Federal Government to settle the claim. 
In accepting freehold title over their land, the traditional owners will have the ability to develop the land economically. 
Economic development led by Aboriginal people is a vital foundation of true empowerment. 
It’s a practical example of how we can work together to recognise Indigenous peoples’ enduring connection to the land and help empower Indigenous communities.

@laurawbush and I join our fellow Americans in mourning the death of a legendary novelist and lovely lady, Miss Harper Lee.  Harper Lee was ahead of her time, and her masterpiece To Kill A Mockingbird prodded America to catch up with her.  Even decades after its publication, her hero Atticus Finch inspires every reader.  As I said when I honored Harper Lee with the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2007, ‘One reason To Kill A Mockingbird succeeded is the wise and kind heart of the author, which comes through on every page.  This daughter of Monroeville, Alabama, had something to say about honor and tolerance and, most of all, love – and it still resonates.’ Laura and I are grateful for Harper Lee and her matchless contributions to humanity and to the character of our country.

Today, April 10th, is my brother Cary's birthday. He will undoubtedly kill me fo posting this particular picture but I've gotten good over the past 4 decades in dealing with his playful wrath. Here we are pictured at Disneyland on the Cars ride with his daughter and my niece Zelah. I've often said that I was blessed growing up with three parents. Cary is just two years older but always was one of my greatest guardians, mentors, teachers and friends. He is truly the epitome of a gentle man, one of the kinder people I know with a depth of goodness and decency in his soul that overflows endlessly into the world. I remember in 1984 I was playing my first varsity football game as a sophomore in High School. It was opening day for Old Tappan, our big game against our rival Demarest. My brother was a lineman and I was a wide receiver. On one play, I shot downfield on a post pattern, the quarterback, Matt Nalbandian,  unloaded a bomb to me. I laid out for the pass catching it right before it hit the ground but the referee called it incomplete. To this day I know I caught that pass and at 15 I was outraged at the injustice of the ref. I got up and began yelling at the official but before I could get far into my tantrum someone grabbed me from behind and dragged me back. It was my brother and he lit into me with a rare ferocity of tone telling me unequivocally that I was to NEVER argue with an official. He dragged me back down field yelling at me about conduct, honor, and attitude: even if I was right about the catch, I was dead wrong in how I was behaving. That was the first and last time I ever raised my voice, argued, or disrespected a referee, no matter how much I may have believed they got something wrong, in my football career. This is my big brother: a man who taught me about manhood; that strength is ultimately not about the physical or about how loud you raise your voice but about how honorable you are, how you treat others and by how well you exhibit grace in this world no matter what the circumstances. Today I celebrate my brothers birth and the incredible life of love he is living. Happy Birthday Book.

I remain determined to work to end the era of hyper-incarceration in our nation. We have more people in prison in America for nonviolent drug offenses now than all the people in prison in 1975. Our Federal prison population has exploded 800% since 1980. And then when people are released we heap upon them lifetime punishments that make it so hard or impossible to get a job, a PELL grant to go to college, a loan, housing, food stamps, to vote, to get certain business licenses and so much more. Further, our drug war disproportionately targets the poor and minorities and fails to adequately help the addicted or mentally ill who are also disproportionately incarcerated. This broken system bleeds billions of our tax dollars which could be better invested to achieve greater safety, economic growth and empowerment of our fellow citizens. I won't stop working and fighting until we end this nearly 40 year national nightmare. Let's all work together to put common sense and justice in our justice system. #libertyandjusticeforall

Here’s the latest in my series of Selfies with My Fellow Senators. Today’s photo is a bonus – I’m with Senator Elizabeth Warren and our nation’s indefatigable Labor Secretary Tom Perez. In my two years in the Senate, Senator Warren has been an amazing partner and leader on issues ranging from providing student loan debt relief to modernizing our federal pension plans so that the professionals managing assets are as diverse as our nation’s federal workers. 
I’m proud to stand with Senator Warren in support of the new Conflict of Interest rule announced today by the Obama Administration that will require retirement advisers to put their clients’ interests first. While most investment advisers give honest advice, some have taken advantage of loopholes in the law that have allowed advisers to recommend products that benefit them, but not their clients. Not only does this go against common sense — it costs Americans an estimated $17 billion each year. 
After a year of fighting for this day, I’m thrilled that we have finally closed these loopholes to protect American families and their savings. #SaveYourSavings

Today in Maywood, New Jersey I visited the Adler Aphasia Center. Aphasia is a neurological disorder caused by damage to portions of the brain responsible for language. We have over a million people in the United States living with Aphasia. Roughly we have 800,000 annual stroke victims, a significant number of whom will have Aphasia. The Adler Center is a vital service for people with Aphasia and their families.  Their therapeutic environment provides rehabilitation services, educational programs, family support and more. For so many it is a lifeline to greater strength, stability and higher well being. Unfortunately they struggle every year depending on private generosity for 85% of their funding. Their critical services should be available to all and because of their work with members, the services they provide help reduce other societal costs needed for their care - arguably saving tax dollars as they empower people to rehabilitate and contribute.  I believe we can and should do more to support centers like this.  I also believe and have called for more investment in medical research. I have specifically been focused on brain injuries and disorders from my AL-TBI bill to my focus on challenges from Parkinson's to Alzheimer's and the need to invest more for a cure.  @Adleraphasiacenter

Heading to the White House for the nomination of Judge Merrick Garland by President Obama to the United States Supreme Court. As Republican Senator Hatch said during his confirmation to the Court of Appeals, "I believe Mr. Garland is a fine nominee. I know him personally, I know of his integrity, I know of his legal ability, I know of his honesty, I know of his acumen, and he belongs on the court." Another in my series of Selfies with My Fellow Senators. This is a "two in one." Here I am with Senators Gary Peters of Michigan and Bill Nelson of Florida. This picture was taken before our hearing on self-driving cars. Both Senators Peters and Nelson serve with me on the Commerce Committee. Senator Peters is the only democratic senator with less seniority than me in our entire caucus! I like to remind him of that every now and then. Senator Nelson is the Ranking Member on our committee and the 11th most senior senator in our caucus. Both of them are valued colleagues. Senator Peters and I share a great enthusiasm for new technology, including drones and smart cars. And I have been grateful for Senator Nelson's leadership on our Committee as a strong advocate for consumer protection, transportation, and technology issues.

Thank you, @nygovcuomo, for today's event calling for action on paid family leave, in the tradition of your great father Mario Cuomo -- a champion of New York’s working families. 
The U.S. is the only industrialized country in the world that doesn’t guarantee paid maternity leave for new mothers. That is unacceptable.

For us to grow as an economy and a society, this must change. Whether nursing a declining parent, tending to a sick family member, or welcoming a newborn – too many Americans face a harrowing choice. They are forced to choose between a day of work they can’t afford to lose, and being there at the most important time in a loved one’s life. That’s why expanding paid family leave is a key pillar of Democrats economic agenda for women and working families: When #WomenSucceed, America Succeeds. Time to #LeadOnLeave!
